channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.S. Embassy Stocks Up on Air Purifiers
item.description: American officials have ordered thousands of air purifiers for their employees as a way to blunt the hazards and the fears that come with Chinese smog.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A sales manager for Blueair, a Swedish maker of air purifiers, said the United States Embassy had ordered more than a couple thousand but less than 5,000 units.

item.title: Praise in Iran All the Way to the Top, Where Efforts Reportedly Preceded a President
item.description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who is said to have allowed secret preliminary talks, called the deal a success and praised the Iranian negotiators.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Many in Tehran received the news of the deal as though waking from a bad dream. Above, supporters of President Hassan Rouhani of Iran.

item.title: India Ink: The Bard of the Tea Stall
item.description: Laxman Rao of Delhi offers something that most tea sellers, known as chai wallahs, do not – books that he has written and published himself.
item.dc:creator: By ZACH MARKS
item.media:description: Laxman Rao at his tea stand in New Delhi on Nov. 7.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Evacuation Questions After China Pipe Blast
item.description: A deadly explosion in the city of Qingdao came seven hours after initial reports of a leak in a pipeline, prompting some news outlets to ask why a more thorough evacuation had not been carried out.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Workers cleaned up oil after a pipeline leak triggered a deadly explosion in Qingdao, China.

item.title: Close Vote Raises Tensions in Honduras
item.description: Hondurans went to the polls on Sunday to elect a new president at the end of a long campaign that has cracked open the ossified politics of one of Latin America’s poorest countries.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS PHILLIPS and ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: A voter in Catacamas, Honduras. The presidential race has been tight after a campaign that stirred the country’s politics.

item.title: Longer-Term Deal With Iran Faces Major Challenges
item.description: The six-month interim plan agreed to over the weekend is intended to allow time to pursue a more comprehensive deal on Iran’s nuclear program, one that will require much tougher choices by each side.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry shaking hands with Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian foreign minister, following the announcement.

item.title: Nuclear Accord With Iran Opens Diplomatic Doors in the Mideast
item.description: For President Obama, the preliminary accord reached with Iran is a seminal moment, but seeking a broader diplomatic opening, experts say, could alter other American calculations.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama boarding Air Force One on Sunday. He said Saturday night that a final agreement with Iran “won’t be easy.”

item.title: Drones Offer Journalists a Wider View
item.description: Remotely controlled aircraft have provided valuable images of events that are difficult to reach, including the recent typhoon in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By LESLIE KAUFMAN and RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: The BBC used a drone to gather information for a report on a high-speed train planned to travel from London to Manchester.

item.title: Israeli Leaders Denounce Geneva Accord
item.description: Officials said that they were not bound by the agreement on Iran’s nuclear program and that Israel would be ready to defend itself without assistance from allies.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: The Lede: In Taunts From Iran’s Ruler, Some Israelis Hear Echoes of Nazi Propaganda
item.description: As Secretary of State John Kerry noted, what might otherwise have been dismissed as harmless name-calling by Iran’s leader is deeply distressing to some Israelis, since he has previously made “very disturbing assertions regarding the Holocaust.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Memo from Germany: Merkel’s Quest for Consensus
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel still lacks a new coalition government, two months after winning re-election, and patience is wearing perilously thin.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: The Caucus: Kerry Defends Nuclear Pact With Iran
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry offered a robust defense of the interim nuclear agreement with Iran, insisting that the deal would make Israel and Persian Gulf allies of the United States more secure, not less so.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: John Kerry speaking after the agreement was reached in Geneva.

item.title: Japan Rejects China’s Claim to Air Rights Over Islands
item.description: Japan’s foreign minister refused to recognize China’s newly claimed air defense zone, warning that Beijing’s move could “trigger unpredictable events.”
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Tensions increased over a disputed group of islands.

item.title: For Sale: Craggy Isle Where Olympic Rocks Are the Stars
item.description: Ailsa Craig, an uninhabited 200-acre island off the Scottish coast, is the source of a distinctive granite put to use every four years for Olympic curling.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: Thousands Protest Ukraine’s Rejection of Trade Pacts
item.description: Marchers in Kiev angrily denounced the government’s decision to abandon broad political and free trade agreements with Europe, which were scheduled to be signed this week.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Thousands of people marched in central Kiev on Sunday to protest the government's abandoning of free trade talks with the European Union.

item.title: Swiss Voters Decisively Reject a Measure to Put Limits on Executive Pay
item.description: While opinion polls showed widespread dismay about huge executive paychecks, many Swiss were uncomfortable with a rigid, government-imposed salary cap.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: Police in India Plan to Question Editor Over Sexual Assault Accusation
item.description: Police officials from Goa are investigating whether the editor, Tarun Tejpal, an anticorruption crusader, sexually assaulted a colleague.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Elders Back Security Pact That Karzai Won’t Sign
item.description: Leaders who had gathered in Kabul asked President Hamid Karzai on Sunday to sign the agreement promptly, but Mr. Karzai said that he wanted to continue negotiations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Hamid Karzai at a loya jirga, a meeting of about 2,500 Afghan tribal elders and leaders, in Kabul.

item.title: Deals at Climate Meeting Advance Global Effort
item.description: Delegates agreed to the outlines of a system for pledging emissions cuts and supported a new treaty mechanism to tackle the human costs of global warming.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: News Analysis: A Step, if Modest, Toward Slowing Iran’s Weapons Capability
item.description: The interim deal brings the Obama administration a step closer to its ultimate goal: lengthening the time it takes Iran to build a weapon.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: President Obama made a statement Saturday night from the White House.

item.title: In South Korea, Delays Drag a Project to Build Homegrown Fighter Jets
item.description: A costly procurement program has deep implications for the country’s military industry and its relationship with United States arms manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: South Korean KF-16 fighters taking off from an air force base during a military drill in Seosan. South Korea envisions a fleet of higher-technology fighters with partial stealth functions.

item.title: Accord Reached With Iran to Halt Nuclear Program
item.description: The United States and five other world powers announced an accord that would temporarily freeze Tehran’s nuclear program and lay the foundation for a more sweeping deal.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian foreign minister, left, with Catherine Ashton, the European Union’s top foreign policy official; Secretary of State John Kerry; and Laurent Fabius, the French foreign minister.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Seize Control of Oil Field From Assad
item.description: A group of rebel brigades captured a large oil and gas field from government forces, opposition activists said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Women in Domestic Slavery Case Lived in a ‘Collective’ With Suspect, Police Say
item.description: Two of three women who say they were held for 30 years in a London home had lived in a group with a suspect in the case, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Sunnis Close Baghdad Mosques to Challenge Religious Attacks
item.description: A move to shutter the sect’s mosques indefinitely as a protest tactic highlights Iraq’s deepening sectarian rift.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
